title: 108_hr5375
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations Accountability Act of 2004". Congress finds allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption in the United Nations Oil-for-Food program, as identified in audits conducted by the United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services (OIOS). The audits revealed mismanagement in the contract for independent Oil-for-Food inspection agents in Iraq, with the contractor failing to fully perform its duties. The OIOS audit concluded that the management of the contract was inadequate and certain provisions were not adhered to. The contractor providing inspection services in Iraq on behalf of the United Nations did not fully perform its contractual duties. The OIOS audit found inadequate management of the contract, failure to maintain staffing levels, overcharging, unprofessional conduct, and discrepancies in reported figures for goods. The United Nations Office of Iraq Programs needs to strengthen its contract management. The OIOS audit found that the United Nations Office of Iraq Programs engaged in unprofessional conduct and reported inaccurate figures for goods. It was concluded that the office needed to improve its contract management and designate a contract manager to ensure services were in line with the contract. The United Nations has a policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states, denying the United States access to audits of the Oil-for-Food Program. The United Nations policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states, including the United States, has hindered their ability to access audits of the Oil-for-Food Program, impacting their ability to fulfill responsibilities in UN programs. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. Congress urges the President to ensure that all OIOS reports are shared with member states without modification. The Department of State must report on financial disclosure rules for UN officials within 180 days. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to the Oil-for-food program and the Office of Internal Oversight Services established by the United Nations. The Office of Internal Oversight Services was established by the United Nations to assist in oversight responsibilities of the Secretary General. Appropriate congressional committees include the Committee on International Relations, Committee on Government Reform, Committee on Foreign Relations, and Committee on Governmental Affairs.
